question: how does birth order affect personality

clueweb22-en0042-05-11599.point_content: Birth order may influence your personality and can be tied back to some of your character traits.
spans: your birth order may influence your personality and can be tied back to some of your character traits

clueweb22-en0042-05-11599.point_content: Oldest children tend to be responsible, well behaved, and possess strong leadership qualities due to the attention they receive from their parents as infants.
spans: firstborn children tend to be responsible, well behaved, and possess strong leadership qualities

clueweb22-en0042-05-11599.point_content: Oldest children often act like a second parent to their younger sibling, causing them to become protective and responsible in nature.
spans: Oldest children, on the other hand, tend to act like a second parent to their younger sibling, causing them to become protective and responsible in nature

clueweb22-en0042-05-11599.point_content: Middle children tend to be very good at cooperation, compromise, and negotiation and often create their own niche to excel at that is different from their siblings.
spans: Middle children are not able to have the title or privileges of firstborns, so they tend to be very good at cooperation, compromise, and negotiation
They often create their own niche, something unique to excel at that is different from their siblings

clueweb22-en0042-05-11599.point_content: Middle children are loyal and faithful in their relationships and tend to be the family peacekeeper—understanding, cooperative, agreeable, loyal, and flexible, yet competitive.
spans: Middle children are loyal and faithful in their relationships and are good at relating to a variety of people, both older and younger
They tend to be the family peacekeeper—understanding, cooperative, agreeable, loyal, and flexible, yet competitive

clueweb22-en0042-05-11599.point_content: Youngest children tend to have more freedom, are often the most independent, more rebellious and attention seeking, creative, social, and outgoing.
spans: The youngest children tend to have more freedom and are often the most independent
They tend to be more rebellious and attention seeking, creative, social, and outgoing

clueweb22-en0042-05-11599.point_content: Only children tend to be more mature, independent, confident, intelligent, more creative yet less agreeable than those with siblings.
spans: Only children tend to be more mature than those who have siblings
Only children are typically surrounded by adults, so they tend to be independent, confident, and intelligent
they often are more creative yet less agreeable than those with siblings are

clueweb22-en0042-05-11599.point_content: Psychological birth order and the child's interpretation of their birth order also affect personality, not just the numerical birth order.
spans: Alfred Adler, the first researcher to identify the significance of birth order, and his successors also talked about the concept of psychological birth order
it is not just the number (where you are in the numerical birth order) that matters but also the way that the child interprets it

clueweb22-en0012-28-03313.point_content: A study published in Brain Imaging and Behavior claims that only children are more creative, yet less agreeable.
spans: A new study published in the journal Brain Imaging and Behavior— “Only-child and Non-only-child Exhibit Differences in Creativity and Agreeableness: Evidence from Behavioral and Anatomical Structural Studies"—claims that only children are more creative, yet less agreeable.

clueweb22-en0012-28-03313.point_content: The study by Junyi Yang and team found only-children exhibited higher creativity and lower agreeableness scores than non-only-children.
spans: Junyi Yang and a team of researchers in China studied the brain’s structural development in only children and in children with siblings. Their results revealed that “only-children exhibited higher flexibility scores (a dimension of creativity) and lower agreeableness scores (a dimension of personality traits) than non-only-children.”

clueweb22-en0012-28-03313.point_content: The study was small, conducted in China, and focused on brain structure rather than behavior, with a sample largely of highly educated young adults.
spans: The study was small, conducted in China, a country with a very different culture than in the US, and looked at brain structure (the structural differences in grey matter) rather than behavior.

The researchers point out that their sample centered largely on “highly educated young adults” and that further studies exploring specific differences between adolescents or younger children could reach different conclusions.

clueweb22-en0012-28-03313.point_content: A large 2015 study by Julia Rohrer and colleagues found no lasting effect of birth order on broad personality traits including agreeableness.
spans: In 2015 Julia Rohrer and her colleagues examined the effects of birth order on personality.
They “consistently found no birth-order effects on extraversion, emotional stability, agreeableness, conscientiousness, or imagination .”

clueweb22-en0012-28-03313.point_content: Psychologists Damian and Roberts commend Rohrer’s study as the most thorough examination of birth order and personality, concluding birth order is not a viable explanation for personality differences.
spans: Rodica Ioana Damian and Brent W. Roberts, psychologists at the Universities of Houston and Illinois respectively, explained why Rohrer’s investigation is so valid for assessing personality traits.

“We commend Rohrer et al. for conducting the most thorough and methodologically sophisticated examination of the relation between birth order and personality to date. [It] clearly laid to rest as a viable explanation for the fascinating differences we see across people and siblings in the typical ways in which they feel, think, and behave.”

clueweb22-en0012-28-03313.point_content: Damian and Roberts’ own investigation of 377,000 students suggests birth order has little or no substantive relation to personality trait development, including for only children.
spans: Damian and Roberts’s conclusion and their own investigation of 377,000 students—“The Associations of Birth Order with Personality and Intelligence in a Representative Sample of U.S. High School Students”—apply to only children as well: “Scientific evidence strongly suggests that birth order has little or no substantive relation to personality trait development.”

clueweb22-en0012-28-03313.point_content: Personality is influenced by many factors beyond birth order, and generalizations about only children’s agreeableness are not strongly supported.
spans: Many parents of only children don’t agree. They are quick to tell me, “Maybe some children are just more agreeable than others, regardless of their family constellations. Our personalities are impacted by so much more than that.”
We need to make sure “not agreeable” doesn’t get tagged on to a long list of stereotypes about only children.

clueweb22-en0012-28-03313.point_content: Frank Sulloway, a proponent of birth order effects, later softened his position, noting birth order differences are modest and there are many exceptions.
spans: More than 10 years after his book Born to Rebel: Birth Order Family Dynamics, and Creative Lives, Frank Sulloway, a strong proponent of birth order effects, softened his position and told a USA Today reporter, "People love to pigeonhole individuals by birth order. These are modest differences. It's important to understand that there are a lot of exceptions to these generalizations."

clueweb22-en0009-77-09221.point_content: Birth order has a huge effect on the development of your personality.
spans: birth order.
Where you fall within the hierarchy of your family has a huge effect on the development of your personality.

clueweb22-en0009-77-09221.point_content: Actual birth order is your numerical placement in the family, while psychological birth order is your self-perceived position, and they can be different.
spans: University of Georgia psychologist Alan E. Stewart, in a field-defining 2012 work, distinguishes between what is known as “actual” birth order and what’s called “psychological” birth order.
Actual birth order, as you might guess, is your actual, numerical placement within your family.
Psychological birth order is your self-perceived position in your family.

clueweb22-en0009-77-09221.point_content: Firstborns tend to exhibit leadership skills, be rule and achievement-oriented, and start with better self-confidence and security due to parents' complete attention.
spans: The firstborn child—or the one with the oldest “role” in the family—is, as you might know, the most likely to exhibit leadership skills, and to be rule and achievement-oriented.

This first child has the privilege of his or her parents’ complete attention—parents who are not already tired out from tending to the needs of siblings. This helps the firstborn start out with a better sense of self-confidence and security.

clueweb22-en0009-77-09221.point_content: Firstborns may experience intense pressure to succeed due to parental expectations and micromanagement, which can create a personality that equates love with success.
spans: First-time parents often place all their expectations—and blame—on this child.
Although he or she may receive all the attention, they may be micromanaged and critiqued at every turn, creating intense, overwhelming pressure to succeed.
This can create a personality that equates love with success.

clueweb22-en0009-77-09221.point_content: Middle children often have calmer parents, learn from older siblings, develop quickly academically and socially, but may feel jealousy and invisibility.
spans: The middle children often find themselves with parents who have hit their stride, and are calmer and more laid-back.
They also have the advantage of having an older sibling to learn from—both from their successes and their mistakes.
This can result in a child who develops quickly, both academically and socially.
They may, however, feel some jealousy toward their high-achieving older sibling who seems to soak up all the attention in the family with their constant stream of “firsts”
The middle child may also occupy a place of invisibility in the family, as the older sibling is praised and the younger sibling is nurtured—they may find themselves alone more often than not.

clueweb22-en0009-77-09221.point_content: Youngest children are pampered and nurtured, develop social skills, are charming and sociable, but may be rebellious and manipulative.
spans: Finally, the youngest child—the baby of the family—will be pampered, nurtured, and looked after like no other, and so may develop social skills that get people to do what they want.
Thus, they may be extremely charming and sociable.
Youngest children may try harder than their siblings to differentiate themselves, and so might take a more rebellious route, getting them into trouble.
Their charismatic attitudes can also tend toward manipulation if left unchecked.

clueweb22-en0009-77-09221.point_content: Personality is shaped most of all by your own choices, and you can change negative traits associated with your birth order.
spans: Your personality is shaped, most of all, by your own choices.
And if you, as an adult find yourself with the negative traits of your birth order? Change it.

clueweb22-en0033-38-09509.point_content: Firstborns score higher on objectively measured intelligence and self-reported intellect.
spans: firstborns score higher on objectively measured intelligence
a similar effect on self-reported intellect

clueweb22-en0033-38-09509.point_content: No birth-order effects were found on extraversion, emotional stability, agreeableness, conscientiousness, or imagination.
spans: no birth-order effects on extraversion, emotional stability, agreeableness, conscientiousness, or imagination

clueweb22-en0033-38-09509.point_content: Birth order does not have a lasting effect on broad personality traits outside of the intellectual domain.
spans: birth order does not have a lasting effect on broad personality traits outside of the intellectual domain

clueweb22-en0033-38-09509.point_content: The effect on intellect persists after controlling for objectively measured intelligence, indicating a genuine birth-order effect on intellect beyond IQ.
spans: this effect persisted after controlling for objectively measured intelligence

clueweb22-en0033-38-09509.point_content: The observed effect size for intelligence and intellect is small, about 10% of a standard deviation per increase in birth-order position.
spans: The observed effect of ∼1.5 IQ points (i.e., 10% of a SD) for each increase in birth-order position
decline in intellect of ∼1 T score (i.e., 10% of a SD) for each increase in birth-order position

clueweb22-en0033-38-09509.point_content: The study used large datasets from three national panels and both within-family and between-family analytical designs to ensure high statistical power and control for confounding variables.
spans: By combining large datasets from three national panels

We furthermore used two different analytical strategies by comparing siblings with different birth-order positions (i) within the same family (within-family design) and (ii) between different families (between-family design)

clueweb22-en0033-38-09509.point_content: The findings contradict lay beliefs and prominent scientific theories that predicted birth order effects on personality traits other than intellect.
spans: This finding contradicts lay beliefs and prominent scientific theories alike

clueweb22-en0030-77-02486.point_content: Birth order theory states the order in which a child was born impacts his or her personality.
spans: Birth order theory was developed by Alfred Adler in the twentieth century; it stated: the order in which a child was born impacted his or her personality.

clueweb22-en0030-77-02486.point_content: Birth order personality traits are shaped by family environments and dynamics during a child's formative years, not innate at birth.
spans: Birth order personality traits are not necessarily present when a child is born into a family.
Instead, in birth order theory, Adler illustrates how family environments and dynamics play a role in shaping personality during a child's formative years.

clueweb22-en0030-77-02486.point_content: Only children tend to be confident, mature for their age, sensitive, self-centered, pampered, and enjoy being the center of attention.
spans: Only Children
These children tend to get much more attention from adults than a child with siblings.

Traits include: Confidence Mature for their age Sensitive Uses adult language Self-centered Pampered and often spoiled Enjoys being the center of attention Feels unfairly treated when not getting their own way May refuse to cooperate with others Desire to be more like adults, so may not relate well with peers Can be manipulative to get their way

clueweb22-en0030-77-02486.point_content: Firstborn children may be achievers and leaders, can be controlling, bossy, strive to please others, and may feel neglected when a sibling is born.
spans: First Child
Since the firstborn child is used to being an only child until the little brother or sister comes along, he or she may exhibit some of the characteristics of an only child.

Also, the firstborn may have these birth order personality traits: Achiever and leader Feels must have superiority over other children May have difficulty when the second child is born, such as feeling unloved or neglected Can be controlling and focused on being correct Uses good (or bad) behavior to regain parents' attention Bossy or authoritarian Strives to please others Reliable Can be protective or helpful towards others

clueweb22-en0030-77-02486.point_content: Second children tend to be competitive, people pleasers, peacemakers, rebellious, and independent.
spans: Second Child
The second child and middle children began their lives, sharing the attention of their parents with the firstborn.
By having an older sibling as a role model, the second child often tries to catch up with them.
Adler believes the second child is most likely to be better adjusted in life.

A second child could be: More competitive Lacking the undivided attention of parents A people pleaser A peacemaker Developing abilities the first child doesn't exhibit to gain attention Rebellious Independent

clueweb22-en0030-77-02486.point_content: Middle children may feel life is unfair, feel unloved or left out, be adaptable, outgoing, and feel 'squeezed' in the family environment.
spans: Middle Child
Many have heard of the "middle child syndrome" and the difficulties these children can present.

Middle child traits include: Can feel life is unfair Can be even-tempered May feel unloved or left out Doesn't have the rights and responsibilities of the oldest sibling or the privileges of the youngest. Adaptable Impatient Outgoing and rambunctious Learns to deal with both older and younger siblings Treating younger siblings rougher Feel "squeezed" in the family environment

clueweb22-en0030-77-02486.point_content: Youngest children tend to be charming, outgoing, attention seekers, may feel inferior, and expect others to make decisions for them.
spans: Youngest Child
The last born child cannot be dethroned by a younger sibling.

Traits of the youngest child: Charming and outgoing Attention seeker Can behave like the only child Feels inferior- like everyone is bigger or more capable Expects others to make decisions and take responsibility May not be taken seriously Can become "speedier" in development to catch up to other siblings

clueweb22-en0030-77-02486.point_content: Birth order alone does not determine personality; multiple factors including biological, social, cultural, physical environment, and situational influences also shape personality.
spans: Most researchers agree there are several influences shaping personality.

Common factors include: Biological: Children inherit many traits and features from their parents. These include intelligence, courage, and physical features. Social: By interacting with others in an individual's social circle, children learn behaviors and thought patterns from their experiences. Cultural: A child growing up within a culture consciously or unconsciously adopts traits consistent with the culture's beliefs and norms. Physical Environment: An individual's surroundings often impact the development of personality. For example, the personalities of those growing up in a rural area are often very different from those living in an urban environment. Situational: As a child grows, they face different situations, which help them adapt and change aspects of their personality. This could be meeting new friends, experiencing a trauma, or, of course, welcoming a new sibling.

clueweb22-en0030-77-02486.point_content: Studies show no significant effects of birth order on the Big Five personality traits, indicating personality formation is influenced by many factors beyond birth order.
spans: In a study of more than 20,000 participants, however, data revealed no significant effects of birth order of the Big Five personality traits.
These include extraversion, emotional stability, agreeableness, conscientiousness, and openness to experience.
This only proves the formation of personality is not simply explained by a child's birth position in the family.
Multiple factors, including socioeconomic status, parental attitudes, gender roles, and social influences, also contribute to shaping an individual's personality.

clueweb22-en0040-52-10013.point_content: First-born children tend to be responsible, conscientious, diligent, structured, and achievers, often favoring Thinking and Judging personality traits.
spans: First Borns Take the Lead
Parents tend to invest much more time in their first borns, and expect them to serve as role models to their younger siblings.
Parents describe their first-born children as: Responsible, Conscientious, Diligent, Structured, Achievers, in terms of educational and career achievement.

oldest children will favor fact-oriented personality traits, namely Thinking (in Myers and Briggs' theory, this indicates a person who makes decisions based on logic) and Judging (the desire to be organized and have decisions made).

clueweb22-en0040-52-10013.point_content: Middle children are often easy going, people-pleasers, thrive on friendships, have good negotiating skills, and are peacemakers, showing a preference for Feeling and Perceiving traits.
spans: Middle Kids Make Connections
Middle kids are in a bit of a bind.
Middle children: Easy going, People-pleasers, Thrive on friendships, Gold-star negotiating skills, Peacemakers
middles would exhibit high Feeling preferences, making decisions based on compassion and what is important to people.
middle kids are 6.93 percent more likely to be Feelers, and 7.23 percent less likely to be Thinkers than if personality had no relationship with your position in the family hierarchy.

clueweb22-en0040-52-10013.point_content: Youngest children tend to be uncomplicated, outgoing, attention-hungry, rebellious, and self-centered, often showing Extraverted and Perceiving personality traits.
spans: Youngests Just Want to Have Fun
youngest children are more willing to take risks than older kids, and they often develop “out there” ways to attract attention, such as being the family clown.
youngest-child traits include: Uncomplicated, Outgoing, Attention-hungry, Rebellious, Self centered
last-borns would be Extraverted and Perceiving for sure

clueweb22-en0040-52-10013.point_content: Only children are confident, perfectionist, independent, outside the box thinkers, and wise beyond their years, often showing Thinking and Perceiving traits with a slight Extraversion bias.
spans: What About Onlies?
Only children occupy a special place. They enjoy the full attention of their parents for their entire lives, and do not have to share resources such as their parents' time or money with anyone.
Onlies are expected to be: Confident, Perfectionist, Independent, Outside the box thinkers, Wise beyond their years
Onlies are much more likely to be Thinkers (rather than Feelers), perhaps because they're not under as much pressure to be agreeable with no siblings about.
They're also more likely to be Perceivers (rather than Judgers), and slightly more likely to be Intuitives (rather than Sensors)
In fact, the data shows a very slight Extraversion bias

clueweb22-en0040-52-10013.point_content: Birth order has a significant effect on personality, with certain personality types more likely to occur in specific birth positions.
spans: The Meaning of Birth Order

Overall, the data suggests that what we assume about birth order and personality is mostly true—whether you're firstborn, middle child, last-born, or only child, birth order can have a big effect on your personality

some types are much more (or much less) likely to occur in a particular birth position. INTJs, for instance, are unlikely to be middle children. ESTJs are likely to be firstborns. INTPs are often only children and ESFPs are almost never only children.

clueweb22-en0038-74-04231.point_content: Birth order has been historically thought to influence personality traits, with firstborns often seen as more responsible and persistent, and later-born children as more sociable or rebellious.
spans: I was the first child in our family. I was also fearful of failure, neurotic, a perfectionist, ambitious—undoubtedly to the point of being unbearable.
My sister didn’t study as hard and went out more, worked at every trendy bar in town and spent many an afternoon in front of the TV.

It seemed to me, all things considered, better to be the firstborn: you had to work harder to expand the boundaries your parents set for you, had a greater sense of responsibility, more persistence, and emerged, in the end, more self-confident.

clueweb22-en0038-74-04231.point_content: Alfred Adler introduced the birth-order effect into personality psychology, suggesting eldest children develop more responsibility and neuroses, youngest are more spoiled and creative, and middle children are more stable and independent.
spans: At the start of the 20th century, Alfred Adler, Freud’s erstwhile follower, the one who believed that the arrival of a younger sibling meant the dethronement of the firstborn, introduced the birth-order effect into the domain of personality psychology.
According to Adler, the eldest identifies most with the adults in his environment and therefore develops both a greater sense of responsibility and more neuroses.
The youngest has the greatest chance of being spoiled and is also, often, more creative.
All children in the middle—Adler was a middle child—are emotionally more stable and independent: they’re the peacemakers, used to sharing from the start.

clueweb22-en0038-74-04231.point_content: Scientific studies have found only very small or no significant associations between birth order and personality traits, with some findings even contradicting common theories.
spans: In one of these studies, two U.S. psychologists analyzed data about the personality traits and family position of 377,000 secondary-school pupils in the United States.

They did find associations between birth order and personality, but besides being so tiny as to be “statistically significant but meaningless,” as one of the researchers formulated it, they also partially ran counter to those predicted by the prevailing theories.

The other study looked for associations between personality and birth order in data from the United States, Britain and Germany for a total of more than 20,000 people, comparing children from different families as well as siblings from the same family and correcting for factors such as family size and age.
Here, the researchers found no relationship between a person’s place in the family and any personality trait whatsoever.

clueweb22-en0038-74-04231.point_content: Firstborns tend to score slightly higher on IQ tests and get more schooling, possibly due to more parental attention when very young, rather than innate personality differences.
spans: Other recent studies, conducted mostly by economists, do find an association between birth order and IQ: on average, firstborns score slightly higher on IQ-tests – they also tend to get more schooling.
This may be due, researchers speculate, to the fact that parents are able to devote more undivided time and attention to their firstborns when they are very small.

clueweb22-en0038-74-04231.point_content: Belief in birth order effects persists partly because differences in behavior are often confounded with age differences and family role expectations rather than inherent personality traits.
spans: One of the reasons belief in the birth-order effect is so persistent, they suggest, is because it’s so easily confused with age.
Pretty much everyone can see with their own eyes that older children behave differently from younger children.

That difference in age might also be the reason that children from the same family are often assigned specific roles, a Dutch developmental psychologist tells me when I present her with the hypothesis of the two U.S. researchers.
Parents tell the eldest to be responsible, and the youngest to listen to the eldest. The behavior that follows from this is an expression of that role, not of a person’s character.

clueweb22-en0025-89-04483.point_content: Performances on psychometric intelligence tests decline slightly from firstborns to later-borns.
spans: performances on psychometric intelligence tests decline slightly from firstborns to later-borns

clueweb22-en0040-07-20307.point_content: Birth order accounts for the differences between kids within families and children take up different roles and personality styles within the family.
spans: "Birth order accounts for the differences between kids within families," parenting expert and author Michael Grose said.
"So kids take up different roles and personality styles and because it happens so young — at a time when we're forming all our habits, characteristics and personality — it tends to stick."

clueweb22-en0040-07-20307.point_content: Parents raise their firstborns quite differently to later born children, affecting personality development.
spans: Each child in the same family is also subject to different parenting.
"Parents will raise their firstborns quite differently to a later born child, that's largely due to focus and experience," Mr Grose said.
